title: 15 Creative Greetings to Text Instead of What's Up

steps.title: Use a funny or cheeky version of the usual "what's up?"
steps.content: Use a funny or cheeky version of the usual "what's up?" Shake it up if you just want to check in with your texting partner (but you're tired of the same old conversation starter). [1] X Research source There are plenty of phrases along the lines of "what's up" that are still more entertaining. Have fun with it, and try a goofy question like: "Hey! What's cooking?" "Hey, Einstein! Still cracking the old theory?" "How's life been sailing lately? â›µï¸" "What's the word, hummingbird?! ğŸ˜Š"

steps.title: Send them a funny meme or video to grab their attention.
steps.content: Send them a funny meme or video to grab their attention. You can instantly brighten anyone's day (and get an exchange going) by texting them something funny. Find a meme, video, or funny social media post you think your texting partner would like. If you don't know their sense of humor well yet, send them something that made you laugh. "I can't stop laughing at this puppy video! ğŸ˜‚ğŸ¶ What do you think?" "You like Lord of the Rings, right? These Tumblr memes are killing me!"

steps.title: Snap an intriguing picture and send it to them.
steps.content: Snap an intriguing picture and send it to them. Give your texting partner little snapshots into your daily life. Whether you take a photo of the view outside your window or your pet being particularly cute, you can wordlessly show the other person what you're up to and prompt them to talk about their day. "Check out this insane coffee art! â˜•ï¸ Where's your fave place to get coffee??" "Found the coolest little park on my run! Have you ever been here?" "OMG, my cat is being too cute this morning. I hope your morning has been just as delightful! ğŸ˜Š"

steps.title: Share little things that show the other person who you are.
steps.content: Share little things that show the other person who you are. Songs and music are a great way to help someone get to know you, but you could also mention a tv show, book, or another fun activity. Ask them what they think of each cool song or movie you text them about, and for a recommendation in return. Over time, you'll learn more about one another's tastes. "I heard this on the radio, and I thought you might like it. Thoughts?" "WHOA. The new BTS music video is ğŸ”¥, check it out!!" "Just finished watching The Batman , and I feel like it's your kind of movie. Have you checked it out yet?"

steps.title: Emojis can perk up a boring text message and make it visually interesting.
steps.content: Emojis can perk up a boring text message and make it visually interesting. They can also add extra emotion and depth to your message; "What's up? ğŸ˜Š" feels much more inviting than "What's up?" with the only difference being one simple emoji. Add emojis to your opening text, or take it a step further and send a text with only emojisâ€”giving the other person a fun message to decipher. [2] X Research source "You'll NEVER guess what happened today! ğŸ¿ğŸ¤ğŸ˜¯" "Good morning, â˜€ï¸! What do you have planned today? ğŸ˜‰ğŸ§¡" "â“â¬†ï¸" and "â“ğŸ‘†" can both mean "what's up?" in emoji-speak.

steps.title: Use a GIF to say hello and entertain your texting buddy.
steps.content: Use a GIF to say hello and entertain your texting buddy. Like emojis, GIFs add color and whimsy to an otherwise plain text message. Rather than texting "what's up," text the other person a GIF to get their attention. Select a GIF you think they'd laugh at or a GIF relating to one of your mutual interests (a TV show or movie, for example.) Alternatively, there are tons of GIFs with "what's up" text pasted over a goofy video clip. Pick one of those and send it to someone so they know you want to chat! If you want to be a little flirty and funny, send the classic Friends GIF of Joey saying, "How you doin'?"

steps.title: Engage your texting partner by asking for their opinion.
steps.content: Engage your texting partner by asking for their opinion. Getting their opinion is a great way to show someone that you're interested in what they have to say and value their thoughts. If you're still building a friendship, it helps you get to know them better. [3] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Start off a text exchange with a quick question about their preferences, which can get them talking even easier than "what's up?" "I can't decide what to have for dinner! Should I make pasta or tacos?" "Important question! Pineapple on pizza: yes or no?" "Idk what to wear for this work event! Can I get your opinion?"

steps.title: Ask subtle questions that let you learn as much information as possible.
steps.content: Ask subtle questions that let you learn as much information as possible. For example, when you ask about the highlights of their day, you're also quietly asking the other person about the things they're most passionate about. Rather than a simple "what's up," ask them more specific questions about their daily life to prompt a more detailed response. "Working on anything exciting at the moment?" "Hey there! Any juice news you wanna talk about? ğŸ˜‰" "How did work go today? Did you get that presentation done?"

steps.title: Pose a creative, open-ended question to keep the conversation flowing.
steps.content: Pose a creative, open-ended question to keep the conversation flowing. Open-ended questions are any query that requires a longer answer than "yes" or "no." Once you get the other person talking, it's easy to have a lengthy and entertaining exchange. [4] X Trustworthy Source Greater Good in Action An initiative by UC Berkeley's Greater Good Science Center promoting science-based practices for a meaningful life Go to source "If you could have dinner with anyone, dead or alive, who would it be and why?" "What are you interested in that most people aren't?" "If you could have a superpower, which one would you choose and why?"

steps.title: Bring up a shared interest between the two of you.
steps.content: Bring up a shared interest between the two of you. When you discuss a common interest, it's easier for the other person to text you backâ€”and because they're passionate about it, they'll probably text you back as soon as possible. You're also showing them that you remember the things you've learned about them, which would make anyone feel good about themselves. "Hey! Are you watching the Packers game this weekend?" "Did you see the news? There's gonna be another season of Criminal Minds ! We've got to watch it together ğŸ˜†" "We should hit up an amusement park soon! You're the only person I know as passionate about roller coasters as I am. ğŸ˜"

steps.title: Text them to share all your spontaneous thoughts.
steps.content: Text them to share all your spontaneous thoughts. You could send an obscure fact you learned or ask them an unconventional yet entertaining question to make them smile. So long as you begin your text with "random idea" or "random fun fact," your texting partner won't be taken aback by the sudden shift in subject. "Random question! Aliens: are they real or not?? ğŸ‘½" "Fun fact! I was today years old when I found out that a group of porcupines is called a prickle. ğŸ¥º" "Did you know that the entire world's population could fit inside Los Angeles? ğŸ˜µâ€ Wild!"

steps.title: Send a puzzle or riddle to get your texting partner's mind racing.
steps.content: Send a puzzle or riddle to get your texting partner's mind racing. If the person you're texting is a fan of brain-teasers, capture their interest with a thought-provoking text. It's more engaging than a simple "what's up," and it's also a fun distraction for your texting partner to think over as they go about their day. "What word is spelled incorrectly in every single dictionary?" (The answer is "incorrectly.â€) "What kind of coat is always wet when you put it on?" (The answer is "a coat of paint.â€) "Today's Wordle has me STUMPED. Any suggestions?"

steps.title: If your goal is to hang out in person, ask them to do something with you.
steps.content: If your goal is to hang out in person, ask them to do something with you. This should be easy enough for friends and familyâ€”just make a lighthearted suggestion. If you're texting a crush, keep your request simple and see if they're interested in engaging with you. Politely and sincerely propose a date idea you think might be fun! "I can't believe we haven't hung out in 2 weeks! Let's hit up the arcade tomorrow. ğŸ˜Š" "I miss you! Wanna grab a coffee this week and catch up?" "I've been really looking forward to meeting in person. Can I take you to a movie on Friday?"

steps.title: If you're texting a crush, ask them flirty questions.
steps.content: If you're texting a crush, ask them flirty questions. Share a few cheesy pick-up lines of your own, too! At the very least, you can make your crush smile and kick off the texting exchange on a much more interesting note. And if you play your cards right, you might even score a date out of the deal. "I've never minded a little cheese myself. On an unrelated note, do you ever feel tired after running through my thoughts all day?" "Do you like cheesy pick-up lines? Because if you were words on a page, you'd be fine print!"

steps.title: Keep it simple and show them you're available for an in-depth chat.
steps.content: Keep it simple and show them you're available for an in-depth chat. Try using a thoughtful and sincere alternative to "what's up" that shows your texting partner you're genuinely curious about how they're doing at the moment. Ask them about their day, how they're feeling, or even ask them if they have time for a longer chat on the phone. "Got time to talk? Let's catch up!" "How are you holding up?" "What have you been doing since we last talked?" "How's every little thing in your life? ğŸ˜Š"
